text: BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity: Eukaryote protists 2 Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes. Last session  Many eukaryotes are not animals, plants or fungi – Alveolates  This session – Stramenopiles – Rhizarians – Excavates  Home work Amoebozoans recording Major eukaryote lineages diversified in Precambrian Eukaryote phylogeny. Image from http://tolweb.org/Eukaryotes Stramenopiles  Typically 2 unequal flagella – Longer flagellum – tubular hairs.  Some lack flagella.  Stramenopiles include – Diatoms & brown algae – photosynthetic – Oomycetes - not photosynthetic. CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php ?curid=447062 Diatoms  Unicellular (some associate in filaments).  Carotenoids in chloroplasts – yellow/brown colour.  Synthesise carbohydrates & oils as photosynthetic storage products.  No flagella (except male gametes).  Almost all deposit silica in cell walls.  Cell wall – 2 pieces – top overlaps bottom. Diatoms  Morphologially diverse – Symmetrical (bilateral / radial).  Sexual & asexual reproduction.  Found in oceans – Dominant in phytoplankton “blooms”.  Common in fw.  On wet surfaces terrestrial mosses. Damián H. Zanette - Originally uploaded 01:59, 16 July 2008 (UTC) by Dhzanette to en:Wikipedia (log). Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=7267563 Brown algae  Fucoxanthin (carotenoid) in chloroplasts.  Fucoxanthin (yellow-orange) plus chlorophylls (green) = brown colour.  All multicellular.  Giant kelps (e.g. Macrocystis) ~ 60 m.  Almost all marine.  Branched filaments or leaf-like growths. Brown algae  Some float in open ocean – E.g. Sargassum – dense mats in Sargasso sea.  Most attached to rocks near shore – holdfasts – Holdfast – alginic acid (sugar acid polymer “glue”) – Alginic acid also cements algal cells & filaments together  Human uses: emulsifier ice cream, cosmetics, etc. NOAA FishWatch (see Gallery), Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=22626320 Oomycetes  Include water molds & terrestrial relatives e.g. downy mildews.  Water molds – filamentous & stationary.  Absorptive heterotrophs – secrete enzymes - digest large food molecules into smaller ones - absorb.  All aquatic saprobic (feed on dead organic matter). Oomycetes  Downy mildews – terrestrial – Mostly decomposers.  Some parasitic on crops – E.g. potatoes e.g. Phytophthora infestans, grapes, avocadoes, etc.  Oomycetes once classified as fungi – Oomycetes cell walls – cellulose – Fungal cell walls – chitin – …Oomycetes more distantly related to fungi than many other eukaryotes. Rhizarians, Excavates & Amoebozoans Eukaryote phylogeny. Image from http://tolweb.org/Eukaryotes Rhizarians  3 primary groups – Cercozoans – Foraminiferans – Radiolarians  Unicellular.  Mostly aquatic.  Typically long, thin pseudopodia (contrast amoebozoans).  Rhizarians contribute to ocean sediments. ja:User:NEON / commons:User:NEON_ja - Own work, CC BY-SA 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=2068966 Psammophile - Microphotographie personnelle; http://psammophile.pagesperso- orange.fr/Pages_IMG/P2085f.html, CC BY- SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=20886070 Ernst Haeckel - Kunstformen der Natur (1904), plate 71: Stephoidea (see here, here and here)Edited for dust, contrast and uneven border, by mixpix 15:02, 24 January 2008 (UTC), Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=3447392 Cercozoans  Diverse  Many forms & habits – Aquatic, terrestrial - live in soil, etc.  1 group possess chloroplasts derived from 2O endosymbiosis – Chloroplasts contain traces of alga’s nucleus. ja:User:NEON / commons:User:NEON_ja - Own work, CC BY-SA 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=206896 6 Foraminiferans  Some secrete calcium carbonate shells  Accumulation shells – limestone.  Live as plankton or on sea floor – Extant spp. 10,896m depth in western Pacific’s Challenger Deep – Don’t secrete normal shells as water CaCO3 poor. Psammophile - Microphotographie personnelle; http://psammophile.pagesperso- orange.fr/Pages_IMG/P2085f.html, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=20886 070 Foraminiferans  Long pseudopodia extend through openings in shell & interconnect to form sticky network – Catch smaller plankton.  In some spp. pseudopodia – locomotion. Psammophile - Microphotographie personnelle; http://psammophile.pagesperso- orange.fr/Pages_IMG/P2085f.html, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=20886 070 Radiolarians  Thin, stiff pseudopodia – reinforced by microtubules. – Pseudopodia – increase s.a.  Flotation - marine environment.  Distinctive radial symmetry.  Almost all secrete glassy endoskeletons – Endoskeleton diversity.  A few reach several mm in diameter – Among largest unicellular eukaryotes. Ernst Haeckel - Kunstformen der Natur (1904), plate 71: Stephoidea (see here, here and here)Edited for dust, contrast and uneven border, by mixpix 15:02, 24 January 2008 (UTC), Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=34 47392 Excavates  Excavates began to diversify ~ 1.5 bya  Several excavate groups lack mitochondria – Derived condition – Life possible without mitochondria.  Excavates include: – Diplomonads & Parabasalids – Heteroloboseans – Euglenids & Kinetoplastids. Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =57229 Zephyris - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curi d=10769382 http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/ImageLibrary/ Trichomoniasis_il.htm, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =739102 Diplomonads & Parabasalids  Unicellular – Lack mitochondria – E.g. Giardia lamblia (diplomonad)  Intestinal parasite – contaminated water.  2 nuclei (nuclear envelopes), cytoskeleton & multiple flagella.  Parabasalids – flagella, cytoskeleton & undulating membranes (locomotion) – E.g. Trichomonas vaginalis  Trichomoniasis – both males & females. Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =57229 http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/ImageLibrary/ Trichomoniasis_il.htm, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =739102 Heterolobosians  Amoeboid body forms in many protist groups.  Body forms heterolobosians resemble loboseans – not closely related.  Amoebas – free-living Naegleria spp. 2 stage life cycle – Amoeboid cells – Flagellated cells  Some Naegleria spp. can cause fatal nervous system disease in humans. en:User:Josh Grosse - Adapted from en:Image:Free- living amebic infections.png, which is from the CDC.This media comes from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Public Health Image Library (PHIL), with identification number #3412.Note: Not all PHIL images are public domain; be sure to check copyright status and credit authors and content providers.English | Slovenščina | +/−, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9075 31 Euglenids & Kinetoplastids  Clade – unicellular excavates with flagella.  Mitochondria – disc-shaped cristae.  Flagella – crystalline rod – not in other organisms.  Asexual reproduction – binary fission. Zephyris - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=1076938 Deuterostome - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=17152 931 Euglenids  Euglenid – flagella from pocket at anterior cell.  Spiralling strips proteins control cell shape.  Some euglenids photosynthetic.  E.g. Euglena spp. fw organism. – Longer flagella used for propulsion (may also anchor) – Second flagellum often rudimentary.  Diverse nutritional requirements – Heterotrophs, autotrophs. Deuterostome - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=17152 931 Kinetoplastids  Includes medically important trypanosomes.  E.g. Trypanosoma brucei species complex – Trypanosoma brucei gambiense – Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense – Trypanosoma brucei brucei.  Immune evasion strategies – Antigenic variation. Zephyris - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=10769382 Protist biology  Protists reproduce sexually & asexually. – Some have reproduction without sex & sex without reproduction. – Some have alternations of generations.  Protists - critical components of ecosystems.  Phytoplankton - primary producers. Protist biology  Some microbial eukaryotes are deadly – E.g. Plasmodium spp. & red tides.  Some microbial eukaryotes are endosymbionts – E.g. photosynthetic dinoflagellates in coral cells – Coral bleaching. Protist biology  We rely on remains of ancient marine protists – E.g. diatoms – petroleum & natural gas source. – Some sedimentary rocks - diatom skeletons  Diatomaceous earth – filtration, polishing & insecticide. – Limestone deposits - discarded foraminiferan shells. – Some places 1g sand = 50,000 foraminiferan shells. – Foraminiferan shells – classifying & dating sedimentary rocks  Estimate global temperatures when shells formed. Summary  Many eukaryotes are not animals, plants or fungi – Stramenopiles  Diatoms  Brown algae  Oomycetes – Rhizarians  Cercozoans  Foraminiferans  Radiolarians – Excavates  Diplomonads & Parabasalids  Heteroloboseans  Euglenids & Kinetoplastids. – Amoebozoans – home work Next session  Evolution & diversity of fungi – Jo Hamilton.
